div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,559] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JULY 31, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subjects to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at TOR (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed direcly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.

Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: TURKISH CUSTOM DUTIES

In another column we publish questions that were asked in the House of Com­mons last week on the subject of the Turkish Customs duties. A tow days ago, it will be remembered, it was stated that the Porte had agreed to all the conditions of the Treaty Powers regarding the forthcoming 3 per cent increase in the Turkish Customs duties. It appears that 75 per cent of the proposed increase is to he remarked, as to ono third for the hour fit of the Turkish Debt and as to two thirds for the Macedonian Budget, the remaining 25 per cent being at the disposal of the Turkish Treasury. According to the calculations of the Foreign Office the sumthus liberated, largely at the expense of British trade, for the purposes of the Imperial Ottoman Government will not be less than £187,400 a year; that is to say, one-fourth of an annual increment of £750,000. Probably, since among the Powers’ conditions are some for the better administration and collection of the Turkish Customs, it will be considerably greater. In passing it may be said that estimates as to British exporters’ share of the additional burden vary from a minimum of 40 to a maximum of 60 per cent. No other State has anything approaching our proportion of Turkish imports. There on this score alone it is impossible for British manufacturers to regard the 3 per cent increase to an ad calorem duty of 11 per cent, with any degree of satisfaction, while it is quite easy to understand that Germany, although her small Tur kish trade has more than quadrupled in Ujq last ten years, may view the change with in difference, if not with composure. This important commercial arrangement itsays the ‘ Morning Post,” a Garman deal pure and simple, engineered in the interests of the German penetration of Asiatic Turkey by means of th3 Bagdad Railway. The re cent debate in the House of Lords of July 4was cordially welcomed by students of our policy in the Near and Middle East, as it elicited from the Undersecretary for Foreign Affairs the news that the Porte had resisted, if not rejected, the British conditions attach- ed to the increase of the Turkish duties, and Lord Fitzmaurice was able to describe the protracted negotiations on the subject as being then no farther advanced than at the time of Lord Lansdowne’s vacations’ office. It is true Lord Fitzmaurice took over to disclose the obviously inadequate giut which Great Britain proposed to demand of the Porte, but the news of the ill reception accorded to these conditions constituted in our opinion the most satisfactory feature of the debate. Bat everything is now changed. Whether they have been modified or not cannot yet be said, but the British terms have apparently been accepted, and after the courtesy notice of a few months’ delay the eight per cent, ad calorem duties will be- come eleven per cent. Turkish bondholders will receive additional security for their com mitmenta, the Macedonian Financial Commis- sion will have a respectable sim to play with and no doubt great happiness will accrue to the Macedonian peasantry pro- vided that the j jalousies of Russia, Austria and Gerrids’, to say nothing of Greece, Bulgaria, and Romania, will allow those on- happy people to live without flying at each other’s throats. Meanwhile, to those who have followed the history of the Bagdad Railway Concession, it is as certain as any Turkish pro- blem can be that this increase in the Customs will be largely devoted to the purchase of German railway material—free of duty, by the terms of the concession and to the completion of the next two sections of the great trunk line which aims eventually at the Persian Golf. Turkish railways hitherto constructed have cost on the average X7J00 per kilometre. Granting the great engineering difficulties of circumventing the Taarua Mountain range, the construction of the next four hundred kilometres, or two sections, of the Bagdad Railway may prove more costly ; but probably a capital of four million pounds will finance the line from Eregli to the vicinity of Aleppo. On the basis of a 4 per cent kilomettic gua- rantee, a simple calculation shows that the Porte’s share of the increased Customs revenue will be ample to enable the promoters of the railway to had the requisite capital. We shall thus have assisted to finance the Bagdad Railway, not, it is fair, to Bagdad, nor to the Persian Gulf, a matter of some fourteen hundred miles, but to the neigh- bourhood of Aleppo, where, by a preconcerted Tarco-German understanding, it is to be linked with the Damascus-Mecca line. If this assump- tion prove correct then it is no exaggeration to say that the news received from Constan- tinople is epoch making. The completion of the Bagdad Railway only as far as Aleppo will entail the predominance of Germ in capital definitely in Asia Minor, and the establishment of a German over lordship of the Gulf of Alex andretta, with its commercial and naval pos- sibilities ; for by the terms of the concession no branch line to the Levaatine coast between Mersina and Tripoli may be accorded to non- German capital. It is in no spirit of captiousness that we vies what it exactly aGerman political and hoanu ai triumph hvfit in tfifiuuR not to r&£rjft Liar apjiamntiy nasty mannm id whinb British nnnstot to the Custom? iDcreast has been giver, for with it goef & pcwsTid argxmezt for proccring az Az^-.L -Greirmaz sniarsunilng on tike matter of the Bagdad Railway. Siaae of oar Germaz contemporaries have repeitodiy boasted that the only permissible name for the great per-jeet wai the “Germin Bagdad Railway.” but until last week there were not a few who knowing the difficulties of nisirigthe reqoirite capital, were content to advocate British co operation. If it should be foand that the 3 per cent, increase of the Tarkish Castoma duties has facilitated an extension of the line to the east of the Tanrus we shall doubtly hear nothing again of British co-operation mtil that portion is well and truly laid.The aim of securing reforms in Macedonia y enabling the Turkish Government to make mod from Imperial funds all deficits in the Macedonian Budget is iu itself laudable. But about two-tbirds of the Macedonian Badget 4oes towards maintaining a force of Turkish troops. In other words, whilst oar Army is being reduced at homo British trade is being crippled to maintain Turkish soldiery in num- bers which even Lord Fitzmaurice admitted to be wholly unnecessary. No doubt the Free Trade belief will be that the burden of the increase in the Cuatouu dues will not fall out.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, JULY 30, 1906
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
Bathing Fatality.
A Barberee, aged 70, was drowned in thesea near Ibrahimieh yesterday while bathing.
San Stefano Theatre.
A new billet, entitled "Georgette,” will be presented at the theatre off the San Stefano Casino this evening.
New Rolling Stock.
The State Railways Administration has applied to the Ministry of Finance for a grant I of L E. 24,000 to purchase material.
Adulteration Law.
The draft of the law re adulteration has been | presented to Hi3 Contentieux of the Ministry I of the Interior by the Sanitary Administration.
The Chafflrs of Faohn.
While at Fachu, Mr. Macbell studied the question of recruiting the ghaffirs of this markaz. from among the Bedouins of the Ababdab tribes.
*he Brindisi Mail.
Owing to delay in the arrival of the P. and 0. tu ail steamer at Port Slid, the Briudisi mail will not reach Alexandria till tomorrow night, by the evening express.
University for Cirls.
According to report, the American Mission has acquired a plot of land near the Boulevard Abbas, close to the seminary of the Dames du 3acr£-Cceur, for building a university for girls.
Attempted Murder.

The Attarin Native Court yesterday sen­tenced Abdalla Hassan, a native of Alexan­dria, to three years’ imprisonment for attempt­ing to murder Ali El-Aini on the 30th ult., when a quarrel totake place between them.
Speoial Lioenoes.

In virtue of a new regulation, a special licence will be required for railway passengers carrying more arms than one pistol. The export of gunpowder is subject to a permit of the Salt Company, which has the monopoly of gunpowder.
The New Bar.

The rumour that Mr. Spezzaropoulo had gold the New Bar building at Cairo to an Anglo-Belgian group has been denied by that gentleman, who declares that he will not sell it Delow £r0,000, and on the condition that it remains the “New Bar.”
New Automobile Garage.

The Sooi^td des Grands Garages has purchased ofM. Gorini his property at Menouf (1900 square metres), at L.E. 11 the metrp, for an automobile garage. The contract was signed for the company by M. Merzbach, managirg director, and M. Comanos, manager.
Minden Day.
To-morrow being the anniversary of the

Battle of Minden, the 1st Battalion Lanca shire Fusiliers will “troop the colour” on Abdeeu-square at 7 a.m. Regimental sports will be held in the Citadel in the afternoon and an open-air concert in the evening. Major Hamilton and the officers will be “At Home” to their friends on Aldeen iquare at 7 a m. precisely. •
Thief Tracked.

In connection with the robbery which took place three months ago at the residence of Baron von Oppenhelm, Counsellor of the German Agency, the Cairo police arrested on Saturday one of the Baron’s former servant*, Salem Ahmed by name. It will be remembered that the robbery was committed daring a dance at the Barou’s, when a gold necklace with pearls, a brooch, and a fan which had been placed on a divan were stolen. Up to Saturday the police had been unable to detect the culprit, who was betrayed by one of his relative*, who had overheard Ahmed talk to his wife about the robbery. The stolen articles have been recovered.
A Romantic Love Quest.

A romantic journey has been taken by M. Jaliau Dupree, a Frenchman, who has followed an American girl from Paris, by way of Egypt, to America, in order to declare his love for her. M Dupree saw her for a moment in the French capital, and took a snapshot photo­graph of her. With only this c’ue to guide him (tor he did not know her name), M. Dupree traced her to Philadelphia and Atlantic City where he was informed of three ladies answer­ing the description of the one of whom he was in search. Selecting the most likely, M. Dupree followed her to Newport, only, how­ever, to find his mistake whan he actually came face to face with her. He is now atNarra- gan-ett proaecating his search, which, he declares, he will continue for years until successful.
New Way of Faying Old Debts.

Saturday morning the body of a native woman was found in a water cistern of a public hath at Ghizeh. It bore marks of blows on the head, body, and neck, which showed that the unfortunate woman had met her death by foal means. The murdered woman was the cashier of the bath”, where her husband & also employed as steker. The Markaz authorities promptly appeared on the scone and opened an enquiry, which showed that Mohamed Mustapha, the woman’s husband, owed his wife an old standing debt, and that fifteen days ago he asked his wife for P.T. 140 more, promising to settle the whole Amount in a short time. The wife gave him the money, but he never paid it back. A few days ago a quarrel took place between the couple over the money, and Mohamed is suspected of having murdered his wife in order to get rid of the debt.
THE BRITISH GARRISON
STATEMENT BY MR. HALDANE
THE EGYPTIAN CONTRIBUTION
FUTURE STRENGTH OF FORCE

London, Tuesday, July 31. Mr. Haldane stated in the House of Com­mons that the forces transferred to Egypt from Crote will form part of the permanent garrison. The 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards will leave for Egypt on the 29th September.

Sir Edward Grey stated that Egypt’s present contribution to the cost of the garrison was £100,000, which represented the extra cost over the £275,( 00 which it cost here. The question of the future contribution for further reinforce­ments was under consideration. The future strength of the British force in Egypt will be about 5,700. The “Times” of the 21st inst. publishes a letter from a correspondent, signing himself “Reformer,” in which ,Mr. Haldane is asked certain questions whioh must ,have arisen in the minds of all thoughtfal observers of the growing military needs of Britain across the ?eas since the proposals for tho reduction of the army wore made public. The correspon­dent says :

Within the last few day4 I have come across two interesting and important statements published in your columns. The one formed the kernel of Mr. Haldane’s elaborate speech last Thursday ; the other was the practical conclusion drawn by Lord Cromej from his review of the internal situation in Egypt. From the first 1 gather that our Regular forces are to be forthwith., diminished by 20,000 men, largely ty a reduction of foreign garrisons, and that yet further reductions may be made as still more battalions can be brooght home from foreign service. From the second I learn that not the least important of tho same foreign garrisons will, in the opinion cf one whose authority can hardly be disputed, require a considerable permanent increase over its present strength.

Are these two things compatible with each other? If not, would it not be better if Mr. Haldane and his colleagues, following the principle of clear thinking enunciated by him, took pause and carefully reflected which of the two interests—the interest of present economy or the interest of our position in Egypt—we can best afford to sacrifice, before they proceed to take action ?

But are we right in assuming that these interests are necessarily incompatible ? Is an increase of the Regular force in Egypt abso­lutely inconsistent with a reduction of the general total of our Regular forces'? The answer to that question depends on the general organization of those forces. If they were organized ou a system, which allowed of their transfer from any one portion of the Empire to another, in accordance with the circumstances of the time, without a general dislocation of the whose military framework, then undoubtedly the Egyptian garrison might be strengthened, not only without a general increase of the whole Army, but even concur­rently with a reduction. If, on the other hand, our forces are organzed ou a system which makes the increase of any foreign garrison by one battalion possible only on the condi­tion that two fresh battalions are raised, the first to furnish tho actual increase, and the second to stay at home and furnish the first with drafts, then obvioasly tho two interests of economy and security can never be perma­nently reconciled. Mr. Haldane Ins declared himself a ooovincel supporter of the last mentioned system. Will he, in the cause of clear thinking, inform us how, after completing his roductiors and successfully re-establishing the artificial pari y of batta’ions fixed by Carlwell a generation ago, he is going to cope with such demands as that just made by Lord Cromer for Egypt, a demand that may be made by South Afroa to-morrow, and by the least expected portion of our Empire the day after.
THE SERSINA TRAGEDY.

In their report to tfie native court of enquiry, the doctors appointed to make the autopsy state that the death of the native fouud dead at Sersina was due to fracture of the skull, caasel by blows on the back part, which had been smashed iu. The fracture might have beea cancel by a kick from a horse.
WISE COUNSELS.
A na’ive sheikh writes to Daoud Eff. Barakat, editor of “A1 Ahram,” as follows :

“Do you not see that th’ngs have chang- ed in Egypt and that our Egyptian writers have accordingly Io change their theme? The Occupation has heroine stronger and more influential than before, and our journalists should therefore keep with it so that it may have coi filence in them. Are not peace­ful and friendly measures better than acts of violence, wbion can only produce severe retaliation on the part of the English ? As for me, 1 am of opinion that the wiser Moha­medans throughout the world should cease to stand or even pretend that they are standing against their European governors. They must, on the contrary, meet their governors on a good understanding, and support them with heart and soul, showing that they are real men in action and active patriots in pul cy having no ev l designs on ilieir superiors. Such a policy will remove every difference arising between Mohamedans and Europeans, and then Europe, which now draws her weapons to face the danger of ‘fanaticism,’ will have no more fear of an anti-European movement, wliile the Mo- ahm lands will eniov reform and prosperity.”
LORD CROMER.
ORDER OF MERIT INVESTITURE
Lord Cromer on Tuesday last attended the Investiture which his Majesty the King held on that day at Buckingham Palace, when he was invested with the ribbons and badge of the Order of Merit.

The badge of this Order is a speoies of cross of red and blue enamel, and its inner portion bears the words ‘ For Merit” in gold letters within a laurel wreath, the reverse containing the royal and imperial cipher : in the case of naval and military men two silver swords with gilt belts are added, and these oross each other. The whole is attached to an enamelled heraldic crown suspended hy a broad ribbon of Garter-blne and crimson, and worn from the neck.

The Order of Merit is designed as a very special distinction for men most eminent in war, ecienoe, literature, or att^ It is generally surmised that the literary character of Lord Cromer’s Reports have marked him out for the oonferment of this speoial distinction.

Lieutenant-Colonel Edgar Bernard, Financial Adviser to the Sudan Government, and Mr. Robert Drummond-Hay, H. M.’s Consul-Gene­ral at Beyrout, who have been respectively appointed Companion of the MostDistinguished Order of St. Michael and St. George,and Mem­ber (fifth class) of the Royal Victorian Order, also attended the Investiture.
RECEPTION IN LONDON.
MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.

The Pan-Islamic Society held a reception last Taeslay at the Criterion Restaurant to meet Mustapha Pasha Kamel, editor of the "Lewa.” Mr. A. Schrawardy, in an address or welcome, said their gueat was- a well-known Egyptian patriot, who had devoted himself to the real­isation of the ideal to reanimate a sense of brotherhood among the Mohamedans and to dispel the ignorance and prejudice prevalent in the West regarding Islam and the Mohame­dans. The Mussulmans of India, in spite of their numerical strength and devotion to the Holy Faith, were powerless because of differ­ence of religions and tongues, and the leader­ship of thought any action in Islam had passed to Egypt. Io his reply Mustapha Pasha Kamel remarked that he was glad to notice the goodwill now being shown towards Islam by the followers of other creeds. They were wise in encouraging this feeling of friendship, for the renaissance of Islam meant the renais­sance of humanity.
THE ASSAULT ON MR. ASHTON

The Native Co irt of Appeal, Tantsh, yes­terday heard the appeal of the Native Parquet in the case cf Ali Nasr Omar, who had been sentenced by the lower tribunal to four months’ imprisonment for assaulting Mt. Ashton, an inspector of irrigation, while in the exercise of his duties. The sentence was increased, accused being condemned to eight months’ imprisonment.
GUM ARABIC EXPORTS.

The exports of gum arabio from Egypt during the month of June last amounted to 543,276 kilogrammes, value L.E. 10,869, as against 806,985 kilos, and L.E. 19,342 during the same month last year. Daring the half- year from January 1 to June 30 the exports amounted to 3,844,881 kilos., value L.E. 76,808, as against 4,543,397 kilos., value L.E. 105,488, during the corresponding period of 1905— which shows a falling off of 698,515 kilos, in quantity and L.E. 28,680 in value. Of the total exports during the six months, 714,618 kilos. (LE. 14,298) went to the United King­dom, 628,852 kilos. (L.E. 12,577) to Germany, 217,136 kilos. (L.E. 4,345) to Austria Hungary, 658,055 kilos. (L.E. 13,165) to France and Algeria, 112,439 kilos. (L.E. 2,148) to Italy, 16,127 kilos. (L.E. 323) to Tarkey, 1/07,148 kilos. (L.E. 22,143) to Amerioa, and 399,506 kilos (L.E. 7,809) to other countries.
TURKISH CUSTOMS DUTIES.

Mr. Lynch asked the Foreigu Secretary in the House of Commons last week whether, in view of the reoent rejection by the Porte of the proposal of the Powers in connection with the increase of the Tarkish Customs duties, his Majesty’s Government were now prepared to consider themselves boand by proposals which were formerly rejeoted, and whioh his Majesty’s Government were in consequence justified in altering.
Mr. Rnnoiman: The reply of the Tarkish Government not having satisfied the conditions asked for the whole question is being recon­sidered. No more definite statement can be made at present.
Mr. Lynoh further asked whether the Porte had now signified their acceptance ot the pro posals whioh they had previously rejeoted.
Mr. Runoiman : A farther Note has just been addressed by the Porte to the Ambas­sadors at Constantinople, but we do not con­sider that it satisfies the conditions laid down by the Powers.

Mr. Goooh asked whether the Government, before finally consenting to the proposed in­crease in the duties, would stipulate that the budget of Macedonia should be relieved of a large part of the military expendituie with whioh it is at present charged.
Mr. Runoiman : It is not possible to make a statement on this point, which is connected yyith negotiations now under consideration, ftnd iu whioh other Powers are concerned.
The Khedive has left Paris for an unknown destination.
Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son are entrusted with the despatch of the mails to his H'ghness.
Our Constantinople Correspondent writes that the Khedive is expected back at Constan­tinople at an early date. He adds that his Highness’s stay will be bat of short duration.
THE ABYSSINIAN AGREEMENT.
THE EMPEROR MENELIK’S REJOINDER.

The agreement conoluded between Great Britain, France, and Italy respecting Abyssinia was presented to the Emperor Menelik on the 18th inst. The British, French, and Italian Ministers in turn calle 1 the attention of the Negus to the considerations in favour of approval of the agreement by Abyssinia, each arguing from his own national standpoint. It is understood that Sir John Harrington, the British Minister, was particularly emphatic in urging the acceptance of the Convention upon the Emperor in his own interest. The Negus promised to take the matter into consideration. He said 1 find that there are many in­teresting points in this Convention, bat since it has taken you some years to coma to an understanding on the subject, I am sure you will oonsider it reasonable that I should take some days for consideration before I give my answer.”

The influence still exerted at the Court of the Negas in favour of postponement is believed in Paris, the “Times” correspondent states, to oome at present from private interests, which, although unable to prevent the work undertaken by the three Powers, possibly imagine that they can secure some advantage by continuing their resistance. No doubt is entertained in Paris as to the ultimate success of the joint aotion of the three Powers.
PLAGUE AT SUEZ.
A fatal case of bubonic plague is reported from Suez to day.
A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Suez in Tarkish ports are subjec­ted to a medical examination, disinfection, and “deratisation.”

Daring the week ending the 29th inst., ten cases of plague were reported thronghont Egypt, i.e., six at Alexandria, two at Suez and two in the Mellawi district. From January 1 to the 29th inst. there were 395 oases of plague, as against 188 in 1905 and 749 in 1904, during the corresponding periods of these two years.

LLOYDS NEW SECRETARY.

Captain Edward Fitzmaarioe Inglefield, R.N., who was last week appointed to the secretary­ship of L’oyd’s, in succession to Colonel Sir Henry Hogier, is a son of the late Admiral Sir Edward Inglefield, K. C. B., and is forty-five years of age. He entered the Royal Navy as a cadet in 1874, and has since been continuous’y associated with the service. Since Jaly of last year, Captain Inglefield has been in command of H. M. S. Antrim, of the First Craiser Sqna dron. Previously—from 1902 to 1905—he was an assistant Director of Naval Intelligence at the Admiralty.

In the ooarse of his career, Captain Inglefield has seen service, for in J884, as a lieutenant, he served nnder Lard Wolseley, in the Nile Expedition, for the relief of General Gordon, and in J 886 commanded a torpedo-boat on the occasion of the international blockade of the coast of Greece, nnder the late Duke of Edin­burgh. From 1893 to 1895, he was first lieute­nant, successively, of H.M. ships Viotoria and , Ramillies in the Mediterranean, nnder Admir­als Sir George Tryon and Sir Miohael Seymour. As a commander he was second in command of the Trafalgar and Royal Sovereign, and in 1899 and in 1900 nnmmandad tha Swallow
NOTES FROM SUAKIN
EXCESSIVE HEAT
(From our Correspondent.)
Suakin, July 23.
Last week heavy sandstorms swept over Suakin and Graham’s Point aud lasted for a few days. Hot winds were blowing and resembled blasts coming cut of a fiery farnaoe.

The railways have altered their working hours, giving a full rest of 3j hours in the middle of the day, owing to the great heat. Up to the present there have been no cases of sunstroke, as last year at this time. There are a few oases of fever at Atbara and Port Sudan, but none are serions.
Colonel Maoanley Bey, C.M.G., R.E, Direc­tor of Sadan Railways, has returned to Atbara from England, where he had been on short leave of absence.
The Hod. Anthony Pelham, assistant engi­neer, Sadan Railways, has also returned from leave of absenoe and is posted to Shendy dis­trict for duty.

Kaimakam Sowerby Bey, R.E., traffic mana­ger, Sadan Railways, has left Atbara for England on leave of absence. Kaimakam Mid­winter Bey, R E, assistant-director of Rail­ways, has also gone on leave, and Kaimakam Longfield Bey, R.E., chief engineer, is acting as assistant director of Railways.

The British steamer Incharran arrived here from England on the 1Ith inst. with a special oonsjgument of coal for the Sadan Railways, and was soon followed by the British steamer Glenfrun with another special consignment of about 5,000 tons. The Glentrnn arrived here on the 19th and, finding the piers occupied by the Incharran, is now discharging into lighters and barges from the buoys. Over 150 Berb3- reen labourers were sent from Atbara to work with the soldiers here in discharging the coal.
TIRESOME DELAY.
EXPRESS FOUR H0UR8 LATE.

Oar Tahta Correspondent reports that con­siderable confusion and delay was caused on the evening of the 26th inst. between Maragha and Tahta by the breaking of the axle of goods train No. 437, which left Maragha at 7.56 p.m. The aooident derailed the locomotive, whioh ploughed deeply into the ground. The train failing to arrive, another goods train was sent from Tahta to discover the cause, and returned with the news.
The passenger train No. 87 ooming from Maragha was more enterprising and disengag­ing the carriages from the locomotive, brought them back to Maragha.

It was midnight before the breakdown train came down from Sohag to the scene ot the aooident, and the line was not cleared before 2 a.m , when the express No. 89 and its relief passed through to Cairo, foar hoars late.
VIVISECTION AT GORDON COLLEGE.

Sir E. Grey has promised to make inquiries in regard to a series of vivisection experi­ments whioh, it is alleged, are being'-per­formed on dogs, monkeys, and other animals by Dr. Andrew Balfoar at Gordon College, Khartonm. He adds that this institution is Dot under the control of the Foreign Office.
WELL WATER FOR ABOUKIR.
Aboukir is to have artesian wells. Arrange­ments for boring these have already been made by a special engineer who last week visited the subarb.

STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The S.S. Persian Prince, with general cargo, left Manchester on the 29 th inst., and is due at Alexandria on or about the 15th August.
PERSONAL* AND SOCIAL
Princess Zffira Faz»l is spending the summer in Larnaca. Her H'ghness likes the palace and intends erecting a summer residence on land wh’ch she his acqu red near the Boa- levard.
Tho grade of Mirmiran is to- be conferred by H. H. the Khedive on Mouheb Bey, Governor of the Suez Canal.
Among the departures by the Khedivial liner on Saturday was Ahmed Bey MohseD, the popular brother of Hassau Pasha Mohsen, who has gme to Beyroat to jein his vHfe and family.
Mr. N. E. Brunyate, Khedivial Counsellor at the Ministry of Justice, will be acting Judicial Adviser during the absence on leave of Mr. William G jodenongh Hayter.
The death is announced of Ibrahim Bey Amin, judge of the Court of Summary Jastice at Benha, and brother ofKassem Bey Amin, Counsellor at the Native Court of Appeal.
Mr. George Herbert Fox, M. A., ?.L.L. (Oxford), has been appointed inspector to the Committee ol Jadioial Surveillance on pro­bation for one year.
M. Revelli, French Vice-Con3al in Alex* andria, is leaving on the 3rd prox. for Fra nee, where, it is said, h^will be appointed to another post.

Spiridion Bey Dimitri, inspector to the Administration of State Railways, has been placed on the retired list and granted a bonus of LE. 1,300 for his servioes. Five other employes of the Administration have also received gratifications on their retirement.

The Saltan of Tarkey was regretting to Sir Nicholas O’Conor, the British Ambassador, at Constantinople, that Mr. Bryce, with his dis­like of Tarkey, and his leanings towards the Macedonians, should be in the Cabinet. The 8nltan was amnsed by the Ambassador’s reply: “Yonr Majesty need not worry about Mr. Bryce, for in Ireland he has a Macedonia ot his own to keep him busy.”
Messrs. Faris M. Kamel and Amin Tannns Laham, physicians, have been authorised to practise in Egypt.
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
We do not hold ouraelvos responsible for the opinions ex­pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit—within certain necessary limits — free discussion.
LACK OF FUNDS.
PLEA FOR ARCHEOLOGICAL SOCIETY.
To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.”

Sir,-—The Archmologioal Society of Alex­andria is doing excellent work, but is con­stantly crippled for funds. May I suggest that an attempt be made to secure resources sufficient to establish it npon a satisfactory basis by means of & lottery, with a large sum as the “gros lot.” It may not*be generally known that the British Museum owes its existence to a lottery, and that the Archbishop of Canterbury was one of its promoters and directors. One hundred thousand tickets were sold at £3 each ; £200,000 was devoted to prizes, ranging from £10 to £10,000 ; and the balance of £100,COO was placed to the British Museum Parchase Fund. With this sum Sir Hans Sloane’s famous library and collection and the Harleian and Cotton manuscripts were acquired, and Montaga House was bought to place the treasures iD.—I am, etc., An Alexandrian.
Alexandria, 30th Jaly, 1906.
A SUGGESTION.
To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.”
Sir,—Permit me through the columns of your valuable paper to offer a suggestion as regards the programmes chosen by the various

British military bandmasters and performed in onr public-gardens. I think a little more discretion might be osed in the arrangement of sneh. So far the mnsic has been solely of a military nature. This may be all right now and again, bat one is apt to get tired of listening to snoh clap-trash as descriptive battle scenes in which it is one oontinnons uproar of rifles, cymbals, and drams. Could not the civilians be considered as well as the military 1 The hand-masters will at once say it is hard to please everybody. Bat where is there a man who can say that he does not like to hear a selection from Verdi’s oompofi- tions 1 Again, our English residents might be pleased with a selection from Sir Arthur Sallivan’s works (I myself being an admirer of this king of Euglish composers). I am snre all lovers of real mnsic will agree with me in my plea for mnsic of a more^lassio and serions nature. Hoping this will receive due attention from the proper qaarter.—I am, eto.,
A Lover of Music.
Cairo.

UNREST IN EGYPT.
A native advocate has sent a letter to a Cairo newapaper on the subject of the preseu* agitation from which we extract the following
passages "

La popalation égyptienne, depuis des siècle habituée à sentir sur elle la main de fer de ses vainqueurs, sultans arabes, mamelouks, ou pachas, s’est tout d’un coap trouvée bénéficier des bienfaits d’un régime d’égalité auqael, par atavisme, elle n’é.tait pas habituée.

Il y eut alors, pendant quelques années, une hésitation. On n’osait pas. Le respect de l’an oien régime subsistait encore malgré tout. Cela fit que la sécurité public ne fut pas trop trou- blée pendant une quinzaine d’années que dura cette transformation. Fuis l’habituJe naquit. Peu à peu le barbarin ooiffé d’un tarbouche sang de bœaf etohamsé de babouches rouges se considéra l’égal de son maître. G était le mo­ment d’appliquer avec justice, mais aussi avec sévérité, la loi qui remplaçait l’arbitraire de jadis, mais qai était aussi la seule sauvegarde de la olasse élevée contre le? fureurs et la féro­cité de la racaille.
C’est cala qui a été négligé. Et notiz q.e les oauses de cette négligence ne sont ni voulues, ni mômes conscientes.
Cela tient à un régime pour ainsi dire forcé.

L’Egypte, pour se mettre au niveau des pays civilisé-*, envoya en Europe 1 élite de sa jeu nesse pour y étudier la loi. Ces intelligences s’épanouirent à l’enseignement des autorités européennes, et de jeunes magistrats imbus des idées les plus avancées des législations crimi­nelles européennes, nous vinrent oleins de zèle et d’ardeur, le cœar rempli d’une immense mansuétude pour le coupable........

Un peu de sévérité dans les tribunaux ; on peu moinsd’acqaittemeots. Que nos magistrats laissent là les idées de Lombroso, q l’ils ne suivent pas à la lettre les enseignements do président Maguaud, et je pense que cela ira mieux. Les petites causes produisent les gratd-i effets. Nous ferons moins parler et cola vaudra mienx. - Z.
THE CAIRO POLICE.

The following example of the animosity with which the native police of Ca;ro regard the Europeans is given by a Cairo contemporary. A complaint arising from the affair has been lodged with the Frenoh Consulate.
Oar contemporary’s version is asfollows : —

Dimanche après-midi à 6 heures et demie, trois messieurs européens montaient, en paisi­bles promeneurs, la rue Mohammed-Ali, lorsque survint an triple galop la voiture d’un pacha. Le oooher envoya un coup de fouet à nos promeneurs qui de se garaient pas assez vite, il attrapa au visage M. Jacques Hornstoin.

Celui-ci réussit à sauter dans la voiture pour arrêter le oocher en faite, ce que voyant, la foule d’arabes et de barbarins qui sommeillaient sous les arcade? se levèrent oomme un seul homme et se précipitèrent sur les Européens. Un jeune homme européen qui passait vint au secours des malmené®, les coups pleuvaient oomme grêle et le malheureux qui avait eseayé de dégager ses compatriotes fut littéra­lement roué de coups. La police tojours in srdisante se montra d’une indifférence inouïe et les chaouiohe?, lorsqu’il se décidèrent à
tkgir, prirent parti pour leurs frères contre es blancs.

Tout le monde fut emmené au Caracol du Mouski, tù l’on dut attendre deux heures avant de pouvoir s’expliquer avec l’aide d’interprètes plus ou moins ignorants. L’officier du poste ne comprenait ni le français, ni l’anglais, ni l’ita­lien !

Disons en passant que l’organisation de la polioeest vraiment intolérable ; mieux vaudrait dire qu’elle n’existe que poar les indigènes, oar un Earopéen au caracol ne peut arriver à se faire comprendre. En Europe, si un Arabe est pris chez le commissaire, il trouve un inter­prète pour la langue arabe, mais au Caire si un Earopéen va au caracol il ne trouve pas d’in­terprète pours’expliquer. C’est raide, ncais c’est ainsi.

M. Hornstein et ses trois compagnons ont dû se contenter d’an procès-verbal, en écriture arabe auquel ils n’ont rien compris. Peut-être ce procè? verbal a-t-il été rédigé contre eux, au lieu d’être pour eux. N’importe, ils ont été forcés de le signer sans savoir ce qa’ils OLt signé!
On conviendra que s’il n’y a pas fanatisme dan s la population, il y a bien animosité^ (soyons larges) contre les Européens.
Le marché est tonjours animé et très ferme; les cours se soutiennent ; à noter de forte-* demande? en Delta Land.

NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
Le Caire, Lundi 30 Juillet 1906.

Au Stock Exffiangé, le Consolidé anglais a haussé de 1/8 de livre vendredi et d’un antre 1 '8 samedi dernier à 87 3/4. L’Unifiée et le-* autres valeurs égyptiennes sont restées inva riées, à l’exception do la D/ra, qui a gagré 1/8 à 16 7/8.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a avancé d’un franc vendredi passé et a reculé de 3 le lendemain à 755. La Barque d’Athènes
a progressé d’nn franc à J48.

Les nouvelles de ltusaie étant, ponr le mo­ment, moins inquiétante? et la tenue des Bourses dirigeantes promettant encore de s’améliorer, notre marché des valeurs encouragé d’ailleurs par la forte hausse du ooton, a continué ce matin à faire preuve de bonnes dispositions. Allure générale ferme et Oours soutenus sur presque toute la ligne.

Dins les compartiment des Banques, la National a avancé à 25 7/16. L’Agricole s’est maintenue à 9 5/8. Le Comptoir a progressé à 6 3/16-1/4. La Cassa di Sconto s’est inscrite à 221 222 et la Banque d’Orient à 134. La Banque d’Athèues est restée à 147 148.
L’action Crédit Foncier a été cotée 756-757; l’obligation à lots ancienne a été recherchée à 339. La Delta Light a avancé à 11 13/16-7/8.
L'Agricole da Nil a passé de 263 à 268-269 et la part de fondateur de 6 7/8 à 7 1/16-1/8. La Nile Land a fait 12 7/8. La Wardan Estate a réactionné à 7/8 15/16.

L’aotion Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été l’objet d’oLe bonne demande et a clôturé à 4 1/16. La part de fondateur Allotment a progressé à 120-121. L’Improvements Corpora­tion a été bien tenue à 4 9/16-5/8. La part de fondateur Enterprise and Development est re­venue à 18 1/2.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont molli à 261-262. Les actions Héliopolis ont été traitées à 286-287 ; la part de fondateur à 8 3/8.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovicb ont été Dé-iociés à 15 7/8 15/16 et les Egyptian à 5 13/16-7/8. Les Upper Egypt ont faibli à 4 11/16-3/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont avancé à 3 5,16-3/8 et les Estâtes à 1 3/4- 13/16. Les Abdy ont été demandés à 1 1/4. Les Walker and Meimarachi se sont raffermis àO 11/16 3/4, les Constructions à 1 7/16 et
les Sucreries à 25-26 franos.
On sait que l’assemblée extraordinaire de l’Egyptisn Land and General Trust (Hooker), tenue le 19 Juillet courant à Londres, a rejeté le projet de fasion avec l’Egyptian Delta Land and lnvestment Co.

Or,ni ressort des explications données par le président de l’assemblée, sir William Haynes Smith, que l’actif actuel net da Trust, tous engagements payés, s’élève à £130,060, sur un capital versé de £100,000.

Parlant de la propriété da Goarbal à Alex­andrie. achetée par le'Trust, le président a dit que le oonseil d’administration a décliné poar ce terrain de construction nne offre donnant an bénéfice de £*0,000. La Société espère tirer an plus grand profit de cette excellente acquisition si la vente en est soigneu­sement faite.
On a fait courir, ces jours derniers, an Caiie et à Alexandrie, le bruit qu’un dividende in­térimaire serait payé le mois prochain par l’Egyptian Delta Land and lnvestment Co.

Si nos informations sont exactes, oette ru­meur ne reposerait, ponr l’instant, sur aucun fondement officiel. Un fait certain, c’est que /as*emblée générale extraordinaire de la Corn panie est convoquée à nouveau pour le 16 Août prochain à l’effet de confirmer les résolu­tions prises le 19 juillet courant et de statuer sur l’augmentation de capital projetée. Peut- être à cette ooca^on/le conseil d’administration fournira t-il quelques données spéciales inté ressentes.

Dans son numéro de samedi pas é, le “Jour­nal Officiel” publie le décret khédivial, l’acte préliminaire d’association, ainsi que les statuts d’une Société formée à Ahxandrie sous la dé­nomination de “Société anonyme des Presses Allemandes”, ayant pour objet l’établissement et l’exploitation d’usines à presser le ooton, l’emmagasinage du coton et autres maroban dises, etc.
Le capital social est de L.E. 45.00?, divin é en 4,500 actions de L.E. 10 chacune, entière­ment souscrites par les fondateurs.
Le premier conseil d’admioistration e9t com poséde MM. Bindernagel, Samuel Ritscher et Hago Lindemann.
Un de no3 correspondants d’Alexandrie nous transmet la note suivante :

“Vous avez annoncé, il y a que’q îes jours, l’achat par la Société d’Ectreprises Urbaine et Rurales d’un terrain appartenant à M. Eicoffier. Or ce terrain, sis a Hadra, mesare 24,0 0 pic» c rré î et non pas 2 000, oomme on <’a dit par erreur. La propriété, située sur quatie rues, e.t entourés d’un mur d’enceinte, avec grai de maison d’habitation en parfai état et dépendances ; le prix d’achat est bien le L.E 17,000. Li Société a fait là une ex collente acquisition, oar le prix revient à en viron P.E 69 le pic, y compris les construc tions, jardin, oto, alors que les voisins de mandent PE. 100 et 120 le pic pour des lots moins bien situés.”

MANCHURIA
PROGRESS OF RAILWAYS
TIMES CORRESPONDENTS
LONDON, July 30

The “Times’” correspondent at Peking, who has recently made a tour in Manchuria, points oat that progress in the construction of rail­ways has been made in the country and states that the Japanese appear to be faithfully ful­filling the evacuation obligations and that the Russians fire likewise withdrawing. An tang, also, is open to foreigners with the exception of the river frontage. Land is available for foreign settlement, which had been expropriated daring the military occupation.
The correspondent urges the immediate resumption of the important British oonces- sions north of the Niachwang River which were made previous to the Boxer troubles. (ZJ-Jw/sr)
CRISIS IN PERSIA
GRAND VIZIER DISMISSED.

div.p: INTRIGUE IN TURKEY.
ARABIAN DIFFICULTIES ATTRIBUTED
TO GREAT BRITAIN.

The high officials of the Palace, and even of the Government, are convinced that the situation oreated in the vilayets of Bagdad and Basra, by the opposition of the Arab tribes to the payment of taxes, is due to British intrigues.

This opinion seems to have been suggest­ed by Germans, who since their concession of the Bagdad Railway are most interested in these regions. Although the 'Parks in ge­neral are more inclined towards British than to Germans, those most influential in the Palace maintain that all the difficulties which have arisen in the Arabio regions— Bagdad, Basra, Nejd, and Yemen—are the work of Great Britain.

This accounts for the fanaticism for some time past against foreigners in the north of Africa. The German Press encourages the 'Parks by such reports as those which have jast appeared in the “Frankfurter Zeitung” and in the “Vossioche Zeitung.” In the former paper it was announced that the PtTte is fitting out twenty six battalions for an ex­pedition to the Sultanate of Nejd, in the hope of securing the succession to the eon of Ibn-el-Rasohid, and protecting him from the aspirations of Mubarak, the Sheikh of Koweit.

It is probable that the Porte will send an expedition to Nejd, but it is incorrect to say that it will be in order to protect the son of Ibn-el-Rasohid against the aspirations of Mubarak, becatf&e the adversary ot the late Emir I bn el Rasohid was Ibn-Sand, and not Mubarak.

The * Vossieche Zeitung,” which doubts that the Expedition will be permitted to advanoe so far as Nejd, cannot ignore the fact that Great Britain recognises Nejd as being Turkish territory, and it is not its intention to take part in the quarrel of the tmirs unless it should he threatened.
CAPE-CAIRO RAILWAY
MR. BEIT’S MUNIFICENT ENDOWMENT

The most interesting and important feature of the will of the late Mr. Alfred Beit is the provision of £1,900 000 for the purposes of the Cape to Cairo Railway. In making this endowment the testator expresses his in­tentions and nmbitions legarding tho fame as follows :

“I believe that by the promotion, construction, and furtherance generally of railways, tele graphs (including wireless telegraphy), and telephones and kindred or other method* of transmission cf person’s goods and messages civilization will be best advanced and ex­pedited io Africa for the benefit of the in­habitants thereof, whether native or immi­grant, and I know from experience how difficult it is at times to find the funds for the construction of such methods of transmission in new and undeveloped countries.
“Now, therefore, I make the provisions here­inafter appearing.

“I give to the said Otto Boit and Julius Charles Wernher and Bourohier Francis Hawksley, of Mincing-lane, London, 120,000 (or all if le?s in number than 120,000) of my fully-paid shares of five shillings each in the Rand Mines (Limited), a jflnt stock company formed under the laws of the late South African Rspablic, and also such sam (if any) in cash as will be requisite, having regard to the value at my death (ascertained by the average market price on that day) of such shares, to make up the valae of the gift in this preseut clause contained to at least £1,200,000 ■

“And I direct that the said Otto Beit, Julius Charles Wornher and Bourchier Francis Hawksley, or other the trastees for the time being under this present clause (hereinafter called ‘the Rulway Trustees’), shall stand possessed cf the said shares and sura (in any) or cash and the investments of whatever kind for the time being representing the same, and whether taken nuder th;s present clause or otherwise (hereinafter called ‘the Railway Fand’), and the income thereof upoQ trust for the purpose ot assisting the promotion, construction, and equipment or fartheracoe of any such methods of transmission, as afore­said, in South and North Rhodesia and Portu­guese Afrioa, both East and West, and German East Africa, and such other pn*ts of Africa as may be traversed in establishing what is known as the Cape-to-Cairo Railway and the Cape-to- Cairo telegraph system, including telephones.
DETAILED CONDITIONS.
“In connexion with the said gift I will as follows:— * w

“ (a) Without any responsibility whatso­ever for loss, the Railway Tr ns tees may give such assistance ss aforesaid out of the capi­tal of theRailway Fund either by subscribing for shares or debentures of any company or companies, whether British, Colonial, or foreign, carrying on part or the whole of its or their business in Africa as above defined, or by guaranteeing or underwriting the issne of any such shares or debentures or by making advance ’ to any such companies, or to any pnblio bodies or persons of Govern­ment, with or without security, and at such rate of interest or with deferred or funded j interest as the Railway Trastees shall in their uncontrolled disoretion think fit, or in any other way (not being by subsidy) the Railway Trustees shall in the like discretion think fit, and may give such assistance out of the ii come of the Rulway Fund by grant­ing subsidies to anv suoh companies, public bodies, persons, oi Government as aforesaid, or in any other way the Railway Trustees shall in the like discretion think fit ; and I expressly declare that the fact of the railway system of Rhodesia or any part thereef having been taken over by or forming part of the property of the Government of Rho­desia or of any federated Government or subject to any poolirg or like arrangement with any other Government or railway system Rhall be no bar to the execution by the Railway Trustees of the powers hereby'
given.

“(h) The Rulway Trastees may accumu­late the income of the Railway Fand, so long as the law allows suoh accumulations being useable as income of subsequent years of the Railway Fund, or may anticipate the same income by borrowing on the secui<y of the capital or income of that Fund ; and as respeots income that cannot by law be accumulated, or is not applied under the provisions aforesaid, the Railway Trustees shall apply it for educational, public and other charitable purposes in Rhodesia or the territories for the time being within the field of the operations of the British South Africa Company.

“(c) In order to carry ont the above direc­tions, the Railway Trustees may at any time dispose of the said shares wholly or partly in their uncontrolled discretion, and apart from the directions given above they may invest the proceeds of such disposition, but, never­theless they may in their like disoretion hold the said shares or any of them or any share acquired by them under the trusts of this paragraph (18) of my will, so long as they, in their uncontrolled discretion, think advi­sable, or as they are not required for any of the above purposes ; and

“(d) Finally, if at any time the Railway Trnstees, or a majority of two thirds of them, shall, in their uncontrolled discretion, consider that the Railway Fand is no longer required for the purposes for which I have established it, they shall apply the Railway Fund, or realize it, and apply the Det pro- prooeds for such educational, pnblio or other oharitable purposes in Northern or Southern Rhodesia (including the establishment, en­dowment. and development of elementary, secondary, and technical education projects) as the Railway Trustees shall in their un­controlled discretion think fit and determine, hnt in arriving at such determination I desire that the then head of the Government of Southern Rhodesia, whether Governor, Administrator, or Prime Minister, as the ease may be, shall be consulted by the Railway Trustees.”
SPORT AND TRAVEL IN EAST
AFRICA.*

Lord Hindlip’s book on sport and travel is of. unequal merit. As a sportsman he is ex­cellent—we must assume that big game shoot­ing is sport, and Lord Hindlip is certainly not a wanton slayer of beasts. As an historian he cuts a poor figare, as narrator of travel he acquits himself creditably ; as a (semi-absen­tee) settler in British East Afrioa he exercises the Britons’ right to grumble against the authorities, and pig headed to a degree some of those authorities appear to be. Every tra­veller, every settler, has the same tale to tell of stupidity and discourtesy experienced at the hands of officials. All officials in the Protec­torate are not alike, and the system is more in fault than the men, but these continuous complaints demand the attention of the Colo­nial Office. While Lord Hindlip is good both for sport and travel, he breaks little ground not already covered by Major Powell-Cotton. And he has not the Major’s power of seeing and describing things. That is not to say that Lord Hindlip oannot tell a good hunting yarn. Take, for instance, this story of the ending of a wounded lioness :—

“ . . . At this critical moment Owad and Darod foolishly let drive, and, as was to he expected, missed. Then she saw us, and promptly charged. It was a fine sight to see her lithe body with head and tail out, and lips drawn back from the teeth charging through the long grass, while we three fools solemnly missed her. Matters had now become decidedly serious, for the Somali’s rifles were empty, and mine was not a very heavy one for the work in hand. Waiting till I felt I\£ould not miss the mark, 1 let drive at th’ shoulder of the advanc­ing animal. As I pulled the trigger I jumped to my left, and at that moment the lioness passed between Owad and myself, sending ns spinning in different directions ; I fonnd myself sitting np facing the animal in its death throes, a dozen yards away, while an inoh of dirt had plugged np the muzzle of my rifle. Owad had already picked himself up, while Darod, the imperturbable, apparently had not moved a step.”
We have indicated that history is not Lord Hindlip’s strong point. Take, as an example, the opening sentence of Chapter IV. : •

“The Kingdom of Abyssinia originally con­sisted of Shoa and Tigre, whose inhabitants were quite distinct from those of the kingdom of Ethiopia, which now, however, forms part of the northern portion of Menelik’s Empire.”

Suoh a statement betrays a confusion of mind as to the facts that entirely destroys con­fidence in the writer’s authority save when he is dealing with matters within his personal knowledge. So that when he writes that the treatment of the Italian prisoners after Adowa was “of too repulsive a nature to be dealt with in a book of this kind,” the wise reader will prefer to take the opinion of those on the spot at the time, men like Mr. A. B. Wylde and the Italian Plenipotentiary, whose evidence is that the European prisoners were in the main very kindly treated. The Abyssinians have many undesirable qualities, and these appear to have so impressed Lord Hindlip that he can scarcely acknowledge any good»in them. His remarks on the cave dwellings and oave dwellers of Moant Elgon show, however, that in things anthropological Lord Hindlip exercises shrewd judgment.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
